original: ENSKOG, David, Professor, Ängby, f Västra Ämtervik, Värml, 22/4 84 av lantbr, pred N Olsson o Karolina Jonasdotter, gm Anna Jönsson. Studex Karlstad 03, fil kand Upps 07, fil lic 11, fil dr 17. E o lektor Skövde 13—18, lekt matern o fys Gävle 18—29, NLatin 29—30, prof matem o mek KTH 30; lär inatem o mek KSHS 33—39. Censor v studex sed. 31. Resor : Letterstedt-stip t Göttingen o Munchen f teor fys stud 22—23, m statsstip till tyska o a tekn högsk f stud av undervisn i matem o mek 31. Av trycket: Skrift oni integralekvat, kinetisk gas- o vätsketeori, radioaktivitet mm. RNO; LIVA; styr.led Sv Fysikersamf, medl Mat o Fys sällsk i Sthlm; Mitgl d deutsch Matemat Vereinigung; medl Ängby båtklb.
translated: ENSKOG, David, Professor, Ängby, born in Västra Ämtervik, Värmland, on April 22, 1884, son of farmer N Olsson and Karolina Jonasdotter, married to Anna Jönsson. Completed high school in Karlstad in 1903, Bachelor of Arts degree from Uppsala University in 1907, Master's degree in Philosophy in 1911, Doctoral degree in Philosophy in 1917. Became a lecturer in Skövde from 1913 to 1918, lecturer in Mathematics and Physics in Gävle from 1918 to 1929, Lecturer in Latin from 1929 to 1930, professor of Mathematics and Mechanics at the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) from 1930. Taught Mathematics and Mechanics at the Royal College of Technology in Stockholm from 1933 to 1939. Served as censor for high school exams since 1931. Traveled on the Letterstedt scholarship to Göttingen and Munich for theoretical physics studies from 1922 to 1923, received a government scholarship to German and other technical universities for studies in mathematics and mechanics teaching methods in 1931. Published works on integral equations, kinetic gas and fluid theory, radioactivity, etc. Member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (RNO); Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities (LIVA); board member of the Swedish Association of Physicists; member of the Mathematical and Physical Society in Stockholm; member of the German Mathematical Association; member of Ängby boat club.
